The Walt Disney Company had been without a separate president since chairman and CEO, Michael Eisner assumed the role following the departure of Michael Ovitz in 1997, after sixteen months at The Walt Disney Company.In 2005 board members Roy E. Disney and Stanley Gold began a campaign called "save Disney" against Eisner. As a result, The Walt Disney Company began a search for the next CEO to replace chairman and CEO, Michael Eisner. Disney and Stanley Gold dropped a campaign called "save Disney" against Eisner and agreed to work with Bob Iger.One of Bob Iger's first major decisions as CEO was to reassign The Walt Disney Company's chief strategic officer, Peter Murphy, and disband The Walt Disney Company's Strategic Planning division. In April 2019 however, the board unexpectedly extended Bob Iger's mandate until the end of 2021, due to the COVID-19 pandemic.
